channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald National Headlines
channel.description: The top National headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: PM questions Abbott's 'character' on boats
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard says her government will consider all recommendations made by an expert panel tasked to look into the asylum seeker issue.

item.title: NSW businesses asked about carbon impact
item.description: The NSW Business Chamber has launched an anti-carbon tax campaign in which business owners are being asked to share their carbon tax stories online.

item.title: Abbott won't dump carbon tax: Gillard
item.description: The carbon tax is likely to stay, even under Tony Abbott's leadership, Prime Minister Julia Gillard says.

item.title: Kochie shows interest in taking dip in bathhouse
item.description: THE Sunrise host David Koch will risk taking a towelling on his next investment - a bathhouse business in Kings Cross.

item.title: Frozen egg birth rate remains low
item.description: WOMEN should not put off starting a family until their 40s in the belief they will simply be able to freeze their eggs and have them thawed later, a fertility specialist says.

item.title: My Three Sons actor dies of cancer
item.description: DON GRADY, who played Robbie Douglas in the 1960s hit My Three Sons and started his career as a Mouseketeer, has died of cancer. He was 68.

item.title: Call for fugitive wanted over beheading
item.description: Police are set to call homes in Darwin's outskirts, in the hopes of closing in on a fugitive wanted over the beheading of a NSW man. Jonathon Andrew Stenberg, 46, has been the subject of a manhunt on Darwin's outskirts since Tuesday.

item.title: Sporting good style
item.description: Blame it on the Olympics. Fashion, like the rest of the planet, is about to high-dive into a period of sporting mania.

item.title: Buying into danger
item.description: Struggling solarium operators are offloading unwanted sunbeds online, prompting calls for a government buyback of the machines to prevent dangerous in-home tanning.

item.title: Less stern approach to access
item.description: Labor is rethinking its policy on jetty leases, reports state political editor Heath Aston.

item.title: Rewrites a blight on Blyton's legacy ... by golly
item.description: The literati snub her, publishers modernise her, but diehard fans are loath to see the Blyton world tampered with.

item.title: Back street office brings further doubts over David Jones takeover
item.description: THE office linked to the private equity firm which has launched a takeover bid for David Jones is a two-storey Victorian premises between a wig shop and a noodle restaurant in the back streets of Newcastle, in northern England.

item.title: On love and evil
item.description: This year's Miles Franklin winner Anna Funder delves into the lives of those who risk everything to stand up against tyranny.

item.title: Bob Katter, MP and dedicated boofhead, knows how to get a point across
item.description: Does Katter make headlines, or make them up?

item.title: Drill down for the best power savings
item.description: According to GoSwitch, the Mistry family could save $270 a year by changing their supplier from Neighbourhood Energy to Red Energy.

item.title: Battle lines drawn as Abbott launches the charge
item.description: Tony Abbott declares a Coalition government would restore 'hope, reward and opportunity' to 'a great country let down by a bad government'.

item.title: Deal or hoax? Mystery surrounds DJs takeover bid
item.description: The office linked to the website of the private equity firm that has launched a takeover bid for David Jones is a two-storey Victorian premises between a wig shop and a noodle restaurant in the back streets of Newcastle in northern England.

item.title: Impact of scheme may not be quite what you expect
item.description: A strange thing happened as carbon pricing laws passed the House of Representatives last October. The share price of BlueScope Steel - one of Australia's most greenhouse-intensive export businesses - rose.

item.title: Tax win for self-funded retirees
item.description: Self-funded retirees are among the biggest winners from the carbon tax.

item.title: Bend a little, Abbott urged
item.description: Julia Gillard urges Tony Abbott to keep an open mind on any proposals to break the asylum deadlock put up by a group of experts appointed after a parliamentary gridlock last week.

item.title: Kitchen sink optional for home cooks with the lot
item.description: High-tech toys are selling like hot cakes to inspired home chefs.

item.title: Left stands on shifting sands in the asylum seeker debate
item.description: He was the man who shut Nauru and ended temporary protection visas. He signed the papers that freed the final 90 detainees there - many of whom he was advised had been assessed as refugees but left on their island prison anyway - to let them begin new lives in Australia.

item.title: A death in Peru
item.description: Six Australians have been accused of an awful crime. Deeply concerned at the developments, Victorian Jessica Vo and the five others decided it was time to speak out.

item.title: Fashion forward fit to be seen as gymwear hits the high street
item.description: Blame it on the Olympics. Fashion, like the rest of the planet, is about to high-dive into a period of sporting mania.

item.title: Have bike but won't be travelling
item.description: Andrew Oosterweghel does not intend to ride the Cadel Evans replica bike he bought for the price of a small car - but at least he has taken it out of the box.

item.title: Newman stamps his mark
item.description: It has taken only 100 days for Campbell Newman to put his authoritative, conservative and frugal imprint on Queensland.

item.title: What changes in Queensland today
item.description: Electricity The standard domestic electricity tariff, known as tariff 11, will be frozen, saving households $120 a year.

item.title: Never too young to run in marathon days
item.description: Young hearts were pumping as the opening events in the Gold Coast marathon weekend got under way yesterday.

item.title: Don't feed the boy protein; it can prove fatal
item.description: In Queensland seven babies are born each year with a little known disorder that severely limits what they can eat throughout their lives, writes Amy Remeikis.

item.title: Anti-carbon tax ads launched by the oppn
item.description: The opposition has launched a major advertising blitz on TV and in print against the carbon tax.

item.title: Swans smash GWS in Sydney's AFL derby
item.description: Sydney have recorded a 94-point win over GWS in Saturday night's AFL derby at ANZ Stadium.

item.title: Bombers cruise past Bulldogs
item.description: Essendon have strengthened their spot in the AFL's top four with an 84-point win over the Western Bulldogs at Eithad Stadium.

item.title: Brumbies beat Force to ruin Sharpe exit
item.description: The Brumbies have ruined Western Force star Nathan Sharpe's Perth farewell, claiming a 28-17 win at nib Stadium.

item.title: Knights beat Eels 20-12 in NRL
item.description: Newcastle have beaten a lacklustre Parramatta 20-12 to claim back-to-back NRL wins.

item.title: 'Completely wrongly accused'
item.description: Accused of murder in Peru, these young Australians are proclaiming their innocence, writes Neil Mercer.

item.title: Eagles put hapless Suns to the sword
item.description: West Coast have kicked 15 of the last 16 goals of the match to send Gold Coast crashing to their 20th straight AFL loss.

item.title: Te'o Queensland's new Origin hitman
item.description: Rookie Ben Te'o says he is not worried about the critics who question his right to play State of Origin for Queensland.

item.title: War Memorial marks Montevideo Maru tragedy
item.description: A new memorial to those lost in Australia's worst ever maritime disaster will be officially dedicated at the Australian War Memorial on Sunday.

item.title: Two more asylum seeker boats - record arrivals for June
item.description: A further two boats carrying 108 people have been intercepted in Australian waters since Friday night, bringing the total number of illegal boat arrivals for June to 1781 people.

item.title: Crows' boss hails 19-point win over Tigers
item.description: Adelaide AFL coach Brenton Sanderson has praised the spirit of his players in their 19-point win against Richmond at AAMI Stadium.

item.title: Magpies march on with victory over Dockers
item.description: Collingwood have consolidated their place at the top of the AFL ladder with a comfortable win over Fremantle at the MCG.

item.title: PM urges Abbott to listen to refugee panel
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard wants Opposition Leader Tony Abbott to consider what a panel comprising a former defence chief says on boat arrivals.

item.title: Gillard insists only Labor can deliver NBN
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard says only Labor will complete the national broadband network despite the coalition's changed pledge to keep it.

item.title: Gerrard says sayonara to Rebels
item.description: Key back Mark Gerrard will play in Japan but hasn't ruled out ever returning to Super Rugby with the Melbourne Rebels.

item.title: Don't let 'Roos run free: Watters
item.description: St Kilda AFL coach Scott Watters says the Saints need to guard against North Melbourne's free-running game style in their round-14 clash.

item.title: PM slams Abbott for Melbourne roads pledge
item.description: Opposition Leader Tony Abbott needs to explain how he would provide $1.5 billion for Melbourne's East West Link, PM Julia Gillard says.

item.title: Fitzgibbon backs Pearce to shine for NSW
item.description: Former NSW and Sydney Roosters star Craig Fitzgibbon says Mitchell Pearce can orchestrate the Blues to a first State of Origin series win since 2005.

item.title: Carbon tax won't interrupt Sunday: Gillard
item.description: Australians are more likely to be watching TV sport or catching up with friends than worrying about the carbon tax on Sunday, PM Julia Gillard says.

item.title: Abbott lays down credentials
item.description: Tony Abbott has touted his credentials to be prime minister, pledging billions of dollars for key road projects in a back-slapping party get-together.

item.title: Sharks dirty about 'soft' NRL reports
item.description: Sharks coach Shane Flanagan has accused the NRL of softening up rugby league following reports against Jeremy Smith and Wade Graham.

item.title: NSW government welcomes Abbott M4 pledge
item.description: NSW Roads Minister Duncan Gay has welcomed federal Opposition Leader Tony Abbott's pledge of $1.5 billion for Sydney's M4 East extension.

item.title: Two boats intercepted overnight
item.description: Two boats have been intercepted carrying 108 people since Friday night.

item.title: Record asylum boat arrivals for June
item.description: A further two boats carrying a total of 108 passengers have been intercepted in Australian waters, bringing the total for June to a record 1781 people.

item.title: More Rich AFL pickings for rising Lion
item.description: The Brisbane Lions are back up and running and face Melbourne on Sunday with the rare tag as overwhelming favourites.

item.title: Moira Kelly named Victorian of the Year
item.description: Moira Kelly, who brought conjoined twins Trishna and Krishna to Melbourne for landmark separation surgery, has been named Victorian of the Year.

item.title: Broncos' Reed cleared of leg fracture
item.description: England international Jack Reed will undergo further scans after he was cleared of a broken leg after the Broncos 26-12 loss to Cronulla.

item.title: Coote says Cleary will boost Panthers
item.description: Penrith fullback Lachlan Coote admits Ivan Cleary has brought significant change to the club, but believes it will benefit them in the long run.

item.title: AFL's Power to face fired-up Cats
item.description: Geelong will be looking to make a fast start against a Port Adelaide side decimated by injury in Sunday's AFL clash.

item.title: Mining magnate accuses Liberals of being 'Stalinist'
item.description: Mining magnate Clive Palmer has slammed the Liberal Party Federal Council meeting in Melbourne as Stalinist after it rejected a move to block paid lobbyists from joining its federal executive.

item.title: Australians ride against Evans in Tour
item.description: Australian pair Richie Porte and Michael Rogers will have key roles helping British rider Brad Wiggins when he takes on Cadel Evans at the Tour de France.

item.title: Lancaster scorches at Tour prologue
item.description: Australian Brett Lancaster briefly had the fastest time early in the Tour de France prologue time trial at Liege in Belgium.

item.title: Digital age takes libraries off the shelf
item.description: There is much more to Ryan Stokes's new role than books, writes Catherine Armitage.

item.title: From little things big things glow
item.description: Scientists are closer to understanding how the universe works, writes Deborah Smith.

item.title: All change, please … and change again
item.description: Radical plans to overhaul Sydney's rail system may come at a cost of comfort and convenience, writes Jacob Saulwick.

item.title: Fantasy spurs teens into social activism
item.description: They have limited disposable income and can't vote, but today's teenagers are wielding more power than ever before, and, increasingly, are helping to shape the political landscape.

item.title: Tears, fears and a country called Greece
item.description: They wept, they whinged, they accused each other of failing to compromise. But at the end of marathon debates, MPs left for their holidays without agreeing on border protection and asylum-seeker policies.

item.title: And now for a racy way to do it tough - tied together
item.description: MORE than 6000 men and women will be diving into mud, climbing through nets and clambering over walls at this weekend's Tough Bloke Challenge, but only a few will be doing it tied together.

item.title: Calls for Thailand to protect tourists
item.description: THE Australian government has called on Thai authorities to clamp down on violence, extortion and scams against foreign tourists on the resort island of Phuket.

item.title: Palmer can't win, but Libs get his point
item.description: Clive Palmer's argument about lobbyists has some support in the party.

item.title: Nine voices its claim to recapture the top spot for ratings
item.description: IN TWO weeks' time, the commercial television ratings year reaches its midpoint. Network executives and programmers typically pause to take stock of the battlefield. What they will make of 2012 is anyone's guess.

item.title: He survived a POW camp, now he's reached a century
item.description: JAMES GORDON LAKE survived friendly fire in the final weeks of World War II, dodged a falling bag of hops at Sydney's Carlton and United Brewery in 1965 and made it through a hip replacement on his 98th birthday.

item.title: Intervention laws linger as NT gets rules on alcohol
item.description: ELEMENTS of the federal intervention in the Northern Territory will continue for another 10 years, after Labor and the Coalition combined to pass the laws before Parliament rose for the long winter break.

item.title: Opposition climate plan could cost extra $24b - study
item.description: THE Coalition's climate change policy could end up costing an extra $24 billion if ''Direct Action'' fails to achieve its assumed ambitious greenhouse emissions reductions from soil carbon and tree planting, an analysis provided to the government says.

item.title: Vera Wang's arrival marks a nice day for a black wedding
item.description: HERE comes the bride, all dressed in black.

item.title: HSU stoush becomes decidedly unhealthy as online warriors spout their venom
item.description: THE warring between the various factions of the dysfunctional Health Services Union might have gone into a temporary ceasefire in the real world, but in the cyber world a vicious battle is being waged.

item.title: Smartphones drive latest wave of cyber-bullying
item.description: THE rise of smartphones has outpaced traditional wisdom on how parents should monitor teenagers' use of technology and created a powerful new venue for cyber-bullying, according to an Australian psychologist who has conducted the most detailed study yet of children's behaviour towards each other.

item.title: Abbott labels eminent panel on boats policy a waste of time
item.description: THE Opposition Leader, Tony Abbott, says the Prime Minister is wasting her time appointing a panel of eminent Australians to end the asylum-seeker policy deadlock because the Coalition will not shift its position.

item.title: People smugglers exploit dangers to cash in on desperation
item.description: ASYLUM seekers have accused people smugglers in Indonesia of taking advantage of the recent fatal sinking of two refugee boats to jack up their prices.

item.title: Stream of arrivals expected at Flying Fish Cove in absence of a solution
item.description: CHRISTMAS ISLAND'S little harbour, Flying Fish Cove, was churned by barges offloading more than 140 asylum seekers from two smugglers' boats yesterday morning, with at least one more expected last night.

item.title: Cycling fans prepare to climb a mountain of exhaustion
item.description: WHEN Jason Pilgrim clips into his bike tonight, he'll be preparing for the world's biggest cycling race, the Tour de France. But he won't be tackling the mountainous terrain of the Pyrenees. Instead, the exercise physiologist will be pedalling in his North Richmond living room.

item.title: Fugitive suspect in beheading was a security guard for Miranda Kerr
item.description: TO SOME he was the tough-talking former soldier who went to Iraq as a contractor to test himself fighting insurgents. He dabbled in local security work, including guarding the model Miranda Kerr and mine sites.

item.title: Rinehart to Corbett: fix share price or quit
item.description: THE gloves have come off in the battle for control of Fairfax Media with its major shareholder, Gina Rinehart, and the company exchanging increasingly personal salvos.

item.title: Super-sized kitchens become cool as home cooking heats up
item.description: THE trend to bigger kitchens - some as long as a humpback whale - in houses and apartments is taking off in what some developers call the MasterChef phenomenon.

item.title: Game changer or game over?
item.description: Treasurer Wayne Swan declares that tomorrow - the day the carbon tax starts - will be a 'game-changer'. Tony Abbott insists it is the beginning of the ''python squeeze''. One thing you can be sure of: this weekend will see the start of a noisy fortnight-long, election-style campaign as Julia Gillard and Abbott barnstorm the country to sell the pros and cons of carbon pricing.

item.title: Digger's Afghan killing was an 'act of murder'
item.description: The shooting of Lance Corporal Andrew Jones by an Afghan soldier 'a cowardly act of murder'.

item.title: Truck plan could backfire
item.description: A new tribunal will set pay rates to try to discourage drivers from working unduly long hours.

item.title: A rare drop, and top of the Grange
item.description: Forget Grange, there's a new flagship in the Penfolds range, that costs $168,000 a bottle.

item.title: Fairfax Media, Rinehart board stoush gets personal
item.description: The world's richest woman and Fairfax in a flurry of heated exchanges yesterday afternoon.

item.title: Smartphones raise the stakes in bullying
item.description: The spread of smartphones has created a new venue for cyber-bullying, says psychologist.

item.title: Asylum rush on for 'good' Gillard
item.description: ASylum seekers are paying people smugglers much higher rates to travel to Australia as they rush to make it while the ''good'' Gillard government clings to power.

item.title: Carbon tax judgment day
item.description: PRIME Minister Julia Gillard has declared that ''practical'' Australians will have the chance to ''judge for themselves'' Labor's historic carbon price reform - which could decide whether she hangs on to her party's leadership.

item.title: Flying Fish Cove more like crowded marina
item.description: Christmas Island's little harbour churned by barges offloading more than 140 asylum seekers.

item.title: Lives at risk as unplanned birth rate doubles
item.description: The rate of women giving birth before arriving at hospital has doubled in Victoria in twenty years.

item.title: Seven crew members going home
item.description: Those to be released are thought to be children and will be returned to Indonesia.

item.title: UN push on refugee effort
item.description: The United Nations' refugee agency has re-stated its willingness to work with Australia.

item.title: All at sea
item.description: In the years that Christmas Island has transformed from a little-known phosphate-mining outpost with hopes of becoming an eco-tourism paradise to what is effectively a prison staging camp, the stampede of government officials and police has placed almost unbearable pressure on the place.

item.title: Egg Corp moves to crack free-range standard
item.description: Moves by the Australian Egg Corporation to overcrowd free-range hens would fail animal protection, small business and consumers alike.

item.title: Hawks add to Blues' AFL misery
item.description: Hawthorn's Lance Franklin has starred in a big win over struggling Carlton at the MCG on Friday night.

item.title: Graham stars as Sharks down Broncos
item.description: Cronulla utility Wade Graham, playing in Paul Gallen's No.13 jersey, starred for the Sharks as they defeated Brisbane 26-12 at Suncorp Stadium.

item.title: Reds too classy for Rebels
item.description: Queensland scored a bonus-point 32-17 victory over the Melbourne Rebels in their Super Rugby clash at AAMI Park.
